data.title: Key facts: Broadcom launches new chip architecture; $73B order backlog; partners with TSMC
data.description:
• Broadcom has launched a new chip architecture, the 3.5D eXtreme Dimension System in Package, now shipping to Fujitsu. This design enhances data movement and power efficiency for AI workloads.1
  • Broadcom has a $73 billion backlog in orders for the next 18 months, mainly tied to AI products, and has gained a fifth major custom silicon customer, likely Microsoft.2
  • Broadcom is partnering with TSMC to create new chips using advanced 2nm and 5nm processes. They plan to ship two products this year and sample three more in 2027.3

data.title: Key facts: BlackRock 2025 revenue at $24.2B; Bitcoin ETF inflows $297M; tokenized funds launched
data.description:
• BlackRock, Inc. reported 2025 revenue of $24.2 billion, a 19% rise from 2024, while net income fell to $5.6 billion from $6.4 billion the prior year.1
  • On February 25, 2026, BlackRock attracted $297.37 million in Bitcoin ETF inflows, over 58% of the day's total, raising its assets in Bitcoin ETFs to $52.50 billion.2
  • BlackRock and Apollo have launched on-chain tokenized funds worth billions, highlighting a significant step in merging cryptocurrency technology with traditional finance.3

data.title: Key facts: Bank of America posts $113B revenue; acquires 3.05% in Umicore
data.description:
• Bank of America reported $113 billion in revenue and $30 billion in net income, driven by increased net interest and noninterest income.1
  • On February 25, 2026, Bank of America reported a 3.05% holding in Umicore, surpassing the 3% legal threshold for direct voting rights and financial instruments.2

data.title: Key facts: Apple seeks dismissal of lawsuit; plans Apple Pay launch in India
data.description:
• Apple has requested a San Jose federal court to dismiss a class action lawsuit alleging it misled shareholders about Siri's AI features and app sales commission compliance.1
  • Apple Inc is in talks with Indian banks like ICICI, HDFC, and Axis to launch Apple Pay in mid-2026, aiming to boost its presence in India's growing digital payments market.23
  • Federal Trade Commission Chairman Andrew N. Ferguson issued a warning letter to Apple CEO Tim Cook, reminding him of Apple's obligations to its customers.4

data.title: Key facts: Apollo Global Management reports $32.05B revenue; partners with BNP Paribas; launches tokenized funds
data.description:
• Apollo Global Management reported $32.05 billion in revenue for 2025, a 22.7% rise from 2024, driven by growth in Asset Management and Retirement Services.1
  • Apollo Global Management is finalizing a partnership with BNP Paribas to boost its European private credit market presence, focusing on loans for corporate and private-equity clients.23
  • Apollo Global Management and BlackRock have launched on-chain tokenized funds worth billions, highlighting a significant step in merging traditional finance with blockchain technology.4

data.title: Key facts: Analysts raise Synopsys earnings estimate by 7.9%; price targets cut
data.description:
• Analysts have increased their mean earnings estimate for Synopsys by about 7.9% over the last three months, despite one analyst making a negative revision to an earnings estimate in the past 30 days.1
  • Rosenblatt cut its price target for Synopsys (SNPS) from $560 to $530, Wells Fargo from $500 to $450, and Piper Sandler from $520 to $430.2

data.title: Key facts: Amazon faces £4 billion liabilities; seeks $50 billion OpenAI deal
data.description:
• Amazon faces potential liabilities of up to £4 billion ($5.41 billion) after losing appeals in two UK lawsuits over market dominance, involving claims from retailers and consumers.1
  • Amazon is in talks for a potential $50 billion investment in OpenAI, starting with $15 billion upfront, with $35 billion tied to OpenAI's IPO or AI milestones.23

data.title: Key facts: Akebia Therapeutics reports 47% revenue rise; Phase 2 trials planned
data.description:
• Akebia Therapeutics saw a 47% revenue rise in 2025 to $236.2 million, driven by Vafseo's U.S. launch. Q4 net product revenues hit $54.3 million, surpassing forecasts.123
  • Akebia Therapeutics is enrolling for a Phase 2 trial of praliciguat for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and plans a Phase 2 trial for AKB-097 in late 2026.4

data.title: Key facts: AT&T settles lawsuit; shareholders to vote on workforce data
data.description:
• AT&T settled a lawsuit with NYC pension funds, allowing shareholders to vote on a proposal for disclosing workforce demographics of its 133,000 employees at the 2026 annual meeting.1
  • AT&T's Chief Data and AI Officer, Andy Markus, emphasized the company's commitment to valuable AI projects, stating they focus on initiatives with clear benefits rather than pilot programs.2

data.title: Key facts: ACM Research Reports $901M Revenue; Secures Equipment Orders
data.description:
• ACM Research, Inc. reported record revenue of $901 million for 2025, a 15% increase. Q4 revenue was $244.4 million, exceeding estimates, with net income of $8.049 million.123
  • On February 26, 2026, ACM Research, Inc. announced multiple orders for advanced packaging equipment from global semiconductor clients, with deliveries set for Q1 2026 and later in the year.4

data.title: Feds Charge Florida Man in Connection With Alleged $328 Million Crypto Investing Scheme — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Kenneth Corbin

Authorities have arrested a 34-year-old Florida man in connection with an alleged $328 million crypto-themed Ponzi scheme. Christopher Delgado, of Apopka, Fla., has been charged with wire fraud and money laundering.

Delgado was the president and CEO of an outfit called Goliath Ventures (previously known as Gen-Z Venture Firm), which solicited money from investors to be placed in crypto liquidity pools, according to the Justice Department. A liquidity pool is a crowdsourced collection of crypto assets that can be used to facilitate buy and sell transactions on a decentralized exchange.

Goliath told prospective investors that money placed in the liquidity pools would "facilitate passive income generation, enhance market efficiency, and provide qualified investors with access to innovative financial opportunities," according to the affidavit in support of the Justice Department's criminal complaint. Prosecutors say Delgado fraudulently told clients that their investments would net them monthly returns, sometimes describing the investments as "guaranteed" or "low risk."

"[I]n reality, the funds were primarily used to pay purported returns to earlier investors, to return principal to investors who requested it, and for Goliath's extravagant business gatherings, holiday parties, and luxury travel accommodations," the Justice Department says.

One of Delgado's lawyers, Sean Shecter, with the law firm Lewis Brisbois in Fort Lauderdale, declined to comment on the charges.

In addition to the alleged Ponzi-like payments to early investors and other expenses, Delgado used some of the money he raised to purchase real estate in Florida, according to the Justice Department. The affidavit details four real estate purchases Delgado allegedly made with investors' money, ranging in cost from $1.15 million to an $8.5 million property in Windermere, Fla., purchased in September 2025.

Prosecutors say the alleged scheme ran from January 2023 through January 2026. Delgado allegedly took several steps to conceal the true state of investors' holdings with Goliath Ventures, including issuing fabricated statements "to show returns where there were none," according to the affidavit, filed by IRS special agent Steven Chandler.

Delgado allegedly offered some clients bogus explanations for why they couldn't immediately redeem their investments and issued some investors more money than they had originally invested, "which allowed Goliath to continue operating because investors did not realize their returns were paid from other investors' money," Chandler wrote.

In late 2025, facing pressure from investors to withdraw their principal or their purported gains, "Goliath delayed payments, provided shifting explanations, and ultimately restricted or terminated investor access to purported information about their investments," according to the affidavit.

The wire fraud and money laundering charges carry a maximum penalty of 30 years in prison.

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Crude Oil Pulls Back Well Off Highs Amid Signs Of Progress In U.S.-Iran Talks
data.description:
WASHINGTON (dpa-AFX) - Crude oil prices moved sharply higher earlier on Thursday but have given back ground over the course of the trading session.

After surging by as much as $1.29 or 2 percent to $66.71 a barrel, crude for April delivery was last seen trading down by $0.11 or 0.2 percent at $65.31 barrel.

The sharp pullback by the price of crude oil came after Oman's Foreign Minister Badr Albusaidi said in a post on X that 'significant progress' was made in the third round of nuclear negotiations between the U.S. and Iran.

Albusaidi said negotiations between the two countries will 'resume soon after consultation in the respective capitals' and revealed 'discussions on a technical level will take place next week in Vienna.'

The comments from Albusaidi who was mediating the discussions between U.S. envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner and Iran's foreign minister Abbas Araghchi, have eased concerns about a potential military conflict.

Ahead of the meeting, the U.S. imposed sanctions on more than 30 individuals, companies and vessels linked to Tehran's oil trade.

U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio said Iran possessed a very large number of ballistic missiles that threaten U.S. interests in the region and it was trying to develop weapons that can reach the continental United States.

Vice President JD Vance said Tehran should take Washington's threats of military action seriously.

data.title: Bloomberg extends financial data to $25B tokenized markets via Kaiko
data.description:
Bloomberg is collaborating with Kaiko, a Paris-based digital asset market data provider, to make Bloomberg’s licensed financial data accessible directly within blockchain environments rather than through traditional offchain databases.

The companies said Thursday that the initiative is designed to address the challenge of inconsistent data across tokenized markets. 

In many tokenized asset ecosystems, companies may rely on different versions of pricing data, security identifiers or reference information, increasing the risk of discrepancies and operational inefficiencies.

By enabling a common, licensed data source to be embedded onchain, the collaboration aims to ensure that market participants reference the same dataset, potentially reducing reconciliation disputes and improving data integrity.

The first use case focuses on tokenized US Treasurys and repo markets operating on the Canton Network, a permissioned blockchain network designed for institutional financial applications. Kaiko launched that data on-ramp service in August.

The integration targets banks, asset managers and other regulated financial institutions experimenting with blockchain-based versions of traditional financial instruments, rather than retail crypto traders.

Questions around data reliability and market size in tokenized real-world assets (RWAs) have surfaced before.

In May, Cointelegraph interviewed Chris Yin, co-founder of RWA platform Plume, who said that the tokenized asset market may be significantly smaller than figures cited by some industry aggregators. At the time, Yin said the sector’s actual size was likely closer to half of what major data sources were reporting.

Related: Hong Kong to link new digital bond platform with regional tokenization hubs

Why data integrity matters for tokenized markets

Kaiko CEO Ambre Soubiran said institutional-grade data is essential for well-functioning financial markets, stating that the collaboration with Bloomberg “will extend the availability of market data used in traditional markets to now support the next generation of tokenized securities infrastructure.”

Kaiko expanded its footprint in the digital asset data sector with its 2024 acquisition of European crypto index provider Vinter, strengthening its presence in regulated benchmark and index services across Europe.

Reliable data has long been a priority in the digital asset industry, where market participants have relied not only on price feeds but also on onchain analytics and sentiment indicators to improve transparency. 

In tokenized markets, particularly those linked to real-world assets like Treasurys, consistent pricing data and reference information help ensure that onchain assets accurately mirror the underlying financial instruments.

Related: Aster’s quiet relisting on DefiLlama leaves ‘big gaps’ in data: Exec

data.title: Installed Building Products, Inc. SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Installed Building Products, Inc. (IBP), a leading installer of insulation and complementary building products, has released its 2025 Form 10-K report. The report highlights the company's financial performance, business operations, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces in the highly competitive building products installation industry.

Financial Highlights

IBP reported strong financial performance for 2025, with key metrics reflecting growth and profitability:

  • Net Revenue: $2,970.8 million, a 1.0% increase from the previous year, driven by higher sales in the commercial end market and contributions from recent acquisitions.
  • Gross Profit: $1,009.3 million, up 1.5% from the previous year, attributed to improvements in selling price, product mix, and material cost management.
  • Operating Income: $386.4 million, reflecting a strategic focus on profitability over sales volume.
  • Net Income: $265.4 million, an increase supported by higher net revenue and effective cost management.
  • Basic Earnings Per Share: $9.76, indicating strong financial performance and efficient cost management.
  • Diluted Earnings Per Share: $9.71, showcasing a solid financial position and profitability.

Business Highlights

IBP's business operations in 2025 demonstrated resilience and strategic growth:

  • Revenue Segments: The Installation segment, including insulation and other building products, formed the majority of net revenue. Insulation installation alone comprised 58% of net revenue in 2025.
  • Geographical Performance: The company operates a national network of approximately 250 branch locations across all 48 continental states and the District of Columbia, with regional distribution operations serving the Midwest, Mountain West, Northeast, and Mid-Atlantic regions.
  • Sales Units: Same branch sales in the residential end market declined by 4.4% in 2025 due to lower job volume. However, the commercial end market grew by 11.2%, supported by strong same branch sales growth and improvements in selling price and product mix.
  • New Production Launches: The acquisition of Carolina Precision Fibers in 2025 expanded IBP's manufacturing operations in Ronda, North Carolina, primarily producing cellulose insulation and specialty industrial fibers.
  • Future Outlook: The residential homebuilding market is expected to remain stable in 2026, with forecasted housing starts anticipated to be consistent with 2025 levels. The company plans to continue its acquisition strategy, targeting at least $100 million in annual aggregate revenue from acquisitions in 2026.

Strategic Initiatives

IBP continued to execute its strategic initiatives and capital management activities in 2025:

  • Acquisition Strategy: The company invested $51.5 million in 2025, acquiring seven businesses expected to contribute approximately $53.3 million in annual revenues. Additionally, four bolt-on acquisitions were completed to enhance existing operations. IBP aims to acquire at least $100 million in annual aggregate revenue in 2026.
  • Debt Management: In January 2026, IBP issued $500 million of 5.625% Senior Notes due 2034, using part of the proceeds to redeem the 2028 Senior Notes, thereby extending debt maturity and improving liquidity.
  • Capital Management: The company repurchased $172.6 million of its common stock in 2025, up from $145.3 million in 2024, and increased its regular quarterly dividends and annual variable dividend by 6%. Total dividends paid amounted to $87.6 million. IBP maintained a strong liquidity position with $321.9 million in cash and cash equivalents as of December 31, 2025, and access to $250 million under its asset-based lending credit facility. The company also amended its ABL Revolver in January 2026 to increase the commitment amount and extend its maturity to January 2031.
  • Future Outlook: IBP plans to continue its disciplined acquisition strategy with a goal of acquiring at least $100 million in annual aggregate revenue in 2026. It anticipates discretionary spending for capital improvements and dividends to approximate 2025 levels. The company expects to use cash and cash equivalents to fund acquisitions and maintain its stock repurchase program. Additionally, IBP plans to manage its debt obligations effectively, with known obligations extending through 2031, and aims to leverage its strong liquidity position to support ongoing operations and strategic initiatives.

Challenges and Risks

IBP faces several challenges and risks in its operations:

  • Market Competition: The company operates in a highly fragmented and competitive industry, facing competition from national, regional, and local companies that may offer superior services or lower prices.
  • Economic Sensitivity: IBP's business is highly sensitive to economic and housing market conditions, including interest rates, inflation, employment levels, and housing demand, which can significantly impact operations.
  • Operational Risks: The company relies on suppliers for building products, and any disruption in supply or increase in material costs could adversely affect its business. Additionally, attracting and retaining qualified employees is challenging in a competitive labor market.
  • Regulatory Risks: Changes in federal and state laws affecting labor, immigration, and environmental regulations can increase operational costs and impact the company's financial condition. IBP is also subject to risks related to sustainability practices and disclosure.
  • Emerging Risks: Cybersecurity threats could disrupt operations and lead to financial losses. The company relies on information technology systems for its operations, and any breach could have a material adverse effect on its business.
  • Integration Risks: The integration of acquired businesses presents risks, including potential adverse effects on operating results and the diversion of management's attention.
  • Interest Rate Risks: IBP is exposed to interest rate risks due to its variable-rate debt. Increases in interest rates could lead to higher debt service obligations and impact the company's financial performance. The company uses interest rate derivatives to hedge against these risks, but there are inherent risks associated with these financial instruments.

SEC Filing: Installed Building Products, Inc. [ IBP ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: Encompass Health Corp SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Encompass Health Corp, the largest owner and operator of inpatient rehabilitation hospitals in the United States, has released its 2025 10-K report. The report highlights the company's robust financial performance, significant operational achievements, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces in the healthcare industry. Encompass Health continues to expand its footprint and enhance its service offerings, driven by favorable demographic trends and a commitment to operational excellence.

Financial Highlights

Encompass Health Corp reported strong financial performance for 2025, marked by significant growth across key metrics:

  • Net Operating Revenues: $5,935.2 million, a 10.5% increase from 2024, primarily due to increased volumes and favorable pricing.
  • Operating Expenses: $4,882.1 million, representing 82.3% of Net Operating Revenues, decreased as a percentage of revenues compared to 2024.
  • Income from Continuing Operations Before Income Tax Expense: $953.0 million, a 27.1% increase from 2024.
  • Net Income: $759.1 million, a 27.2% increase from 2024, reflecting strong revenue growth and operational efficiency.
  • Net Income Attributable to Encompass Health: $566.2 million, a 24.2% increase from 2024.
  • Basic Earnings Per Share Attributable to Encompass Health Common Shareholders: $5.62, up from $4.53 in 2024.
  • Diluted Earnings Per Share Attributable to Encompass Health Common Shareholders: $5.54, up from $4.46 in 2024.

Business Highlights

Encompass Health Corp's operational performance in 2025 was marked by significant achievements and growth:

  • Revenue Segments: Approximately 65% of net operating revenues were derived from fee-for-service Medicare, 16% from Medicare Advantage, with the remaining revenue coming from managed care, Medicaid, and other sources.
  • Geographical Performance: The company operates hospitals in 39 states and Puerto Rico, with significant concentrations in Florida and Texas, supporting its position as the largest owner and operator of inpatient rehabilitation hospitals in the nation.
  • Sales Units: The company reported 263,299 discharges in 2025, an increase from 248,498 in 2024, reflecting growth in patient volume.
  • New Production Launches: In 2025, the company expanded its capacity by adding 177 new beds to existing hospitals and opened several new inpatient rehabilitation hospitals, including locations in Athens, Georgia; Fort Myers, Florida; Daytona Beach, Florida; Danbury, Connecticut; St. Petersburg, Florida; Amarillo, Texas; and Lake Worth, Florida.
  • Future Outlook: The company remains optimistic about its growth prospects, driven by demographic trends such as an aging population, which is expected to increase demand for inpatient rehabilitation services. The company plans to continue expanding its network of hospitals and adding capacity to existing facilities.

Strategic Initiatives

Encompass Health Corp has undertaken several strategic initiatives to support its long-term growth and financial stability:

  • Development and Expansion: The company continued its development and expansion efforts by opening several new inpatient rehabilitation hospitals in 2025, including joint ventures in Georgia, Florida, Connecticut, and Texas. It also announced plans for additional hospitals expected to open in 2026 and beyond, with a focus on increasing capacity and expanding its geographic footprint.
  • Capital Management: In 2025, the company redeemed the remaining $100 million of its 5.75% Senior Notes due 2025, using cash on hand and capacity under its revolving credit facility. The company maintained a strong balance sheet with no significant debt maturities until 2028. It also repurchased 1.5 million shares of its common stock for $158 million and increased its quarterly dividend to $0.19 per share. The company has significant availability under its revolving credit facility and plans to continue shareholder distributions through stock repurchases and dividends.
  • Future Outlook: The company remains optimistic about its long-term prospects, driven by demographic trends such as an aging population, which is expected to increase demand for its services. It plans to invest in growth opportunities, including new hospital openings and capacity expansions, while maintaining a flexible capital structure. The company anticipates continued strong cash flows from operations to support these initiatives and expects to pay approximately $150 million to $180 million in cash income taxes in 2026.

Challenges and Risks

Encompass Health Corp faces several challenges and risks that could impact its operations and financial performance:

  • Reimbursement Risks: The company faces significant reimbursement risks due to potential reductions or changes in reimbursement from government and third-party payors, particularly Medicare and Medicaid. Legislative changes, such as the ACA and the Budget Control Act, have historically impacted reimbursement rates, and future initiatives could further affect revenues. The introduction of the One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA) and potential changes under the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act could also lead to reimbursement reductions.
  • Operational Risks: The potential for audits and payment denials from Medicare and other payors could negatively impact cash flows and financial results. The company is subject to various audit programs, including those conducted by Recovery Audit Contractors (RACs) and Uniform Program Integrity Contractors (UPICs), which may result in significant overpayment determinations and require substantial resources to address.
  • Regulatory Risks: The evolving healthcare delivery system, including alternative payment models and value-based purchasing initiatives, poses regulatory risks. The implementation of models like the Transforming Episode Accountability Model (TEAM) and the Comprehensive Care for Joint Replacement (CJR) model could impact reimbursement and operational strategies. Additionally, the Review Choice Demonstration (RCD) program poses challenges in terms of compliance and potential revenue impacts.
  • Compliance Risks: The company faces risks related to compliance with extensive healthcare laws and regulations, including the 60% Rule for inpatient rehabilitation facilities, anti-kickback laws, and privacy regulations under HIPAA and the HITECH Act. Non-compliance could result in significant penalties, including exclusion from Medicare and Medicaid programs.
  • Market Risks: The company is exposed to market risks, including pressures from managed care and third-party payors to control healthcare costs, which could affect reimbursement rates and profitability. Additionally, the company must navigate the complexities of billing and collection processes, which are subject to regulatory constraints and could impact liquidity and financial performance.

SEC Filing: Encompass Health Corp [ EHC ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: TopBuild Corp reports results for the quarter ended September 30 - Earnings Summary
data.description:
• TopBuild Corp reported quarterly adjusted earnings of $4.50​​ per share for the quarter ended September 30, lower than the same quarter last year, when the company reported EPS of $5.68. The mean expectation of fifteen analysts for the quarter was for earnings of $4.54 per share. Wall Street expected results to range from $4.99 to $5.02 per share.

  • Revenue rose 1.4% to $1.49 billion from a year ago; analysts expected $1.49 billion.

  • TopBuild Corp's reported EPS for the quarter was $5.04​.

  • The company reported quarterly net income of $104.52 million.

  • TopBuild Corp shares had risen by 16.3% this quarter.

FORECAST CHANGES

  • The mean earnings estimate of analysts had fallen by about 0.7% in the last three months.​

  • In the last 30 days, there have been no earnings estimate revisions by analysts covering the company.

RECOMMENDATIONS

  • The current average analyst rating on the shares is "buy" and the breakdown of recommendations is 12 "strong buy" or "buy," 4 "hold" and no "sell" or "strong sell." The average consensus recommendation for the construction & engineering peer group is also "buy"

  • Wall Street's median 12-month price target for TopBuild Corp is $510.00, about 4.8% above its last closing price of $485.32

This summary was machine generated from LSEG data February 26 at 07:57 p.m. UTC. ​All figures in US dollars unless otherwise stated. data.title: Communique from extraordinary shareholders’ meeting in Mentice AB
data.description:
An extraordinary shareholders’ meeting was held in Mentice AB (“the Company”) on February 26, 2026. Below follows a summary of the resolutions made at the meeting.

Resolution on the number of board members

The shareholders’ meeting resolved that the board of directors shall consist of four ordinary members elected by the shareholders’ meeting, without deputies.

Election of board members

The shareholders’ meeting resolved that board members Johann Koss, Lawrence D. Howell and Denis Gestin be re-elected as board members. Göran Malmberg, previously CEO of the Company, was elected, for the period until the next annual shareholders’ meeting, as a new board member in the Company. Former board members David J. Ballard, Eola Änggård Runsten and Magnus Nilsson stepped down from the board.

Johann Koss has been a member of the board since 2015, Lawrence D. Howell has been involved with the Company as an owner and board member since 2005 and Denis Gestin has been a member of the board since 2019. Göran Malmberg served as a board member in 2007 before assuming the role of CEO in January 2008, a position he held until December 31, 2024, when Frans Venker assumed the role as new CEO. Since 2025, Göran Malmberg serves as an advisor to the Company and its owners, and following the recent change of ownership, he now in addition assumes the role of board member. Göran Malmberg holds 782,837 shares in the Company.

“I would like to thank Magnus Nilsson, Eola Änggård Runsten and David J. Ballard for their valuable contributions to the board over the past years”, says Frans Venker, CEO of Mentice AB. “At the same time, I warmly welcome the newly composed board as we continue executing our strategy and taking Mentice to the next level.”

“I am excited about the opportunity to work with Frans and the board to support Mentice’s continued growth”, says Göran Malmberg. “It is inspiring to see the positive development over the past quarters, and I look forward to working with this focused and experienced board and management team in a company I am deeply passionate about.”

More information regarding the members of the board of directors is presented on the Company website,investor.mentice.com.

Election of chairman of the board

The shareholders’ meeting resolved that Göran Malmberg be appointed as chairman of the board.

The resolutions in their entirety

The resolutions in their entirety are available at the Company’s webpage,investor.mentice.com.

For more information, please contact:

Frans Venker, CEO, Mentice

Email:frans.venker@mentice.com

Mobile +46 (0) 735 25 30 81

About Mentice

Mentice (STO: MNTC) is the world leader in proficiency based simulation solutions for image guided therapies. Our solutions help healthcare professionals acquire, retain, and enhance their procedural skills driving improved productivity and outcomes. Mentice solutions are scientifically validated and have been specifically developed for healthcare providers and the medical device industry. Neurovascular, cardiovascular, and peripheral interventions are just some of the clinical areas covered by our solutions. Learn more about the features and benefits of Mentice solutions at:www.mentice.com

Marketplace| Nasdaq First North Premium Growth Market, Stockholm | Ticker symbol MNTC

Certified Adviser| FNCA Sweden AB

Attachments

Communique from extraordinary shareholders’ meeting in Mentice AB

data.title: Uniserve Announces Grant of Incentive Stock Options
data.description:
(TheNewswire)

    Vancouver, BC: February 26, 2026  -TheNewswire – Uniserve
    Communications Corporation (the “Company” or “Uniserve”)
    , a Canadian provider of managed IT, ISP, cloud, anddata centre services, wishes to announce that it has granted,effective today, an aggregate of 525,000 stock options (each an“Option) to certain consultants of the Company in accordance withthe Company’s Rolling Stock Option Plan. Each Option is exercisableinto one common share in the capital of the Company (each a“Share”) at a price of $0.62 per Share, being the price of theCompany’s shares on the last closing price on the TSX VentureExchange on February 25, 2026. The options granted are exercisable fora two year term expiring February 26, 2028, and vests immediately, andis subject to a four month hold period to June 27, 2026.

    About Uniserve

    Uniserve delivers secure, reliable, and customized ITsolutions that power your business forward. With offices in Vancouver,Calgary, and Waterloo, Uniserve provides a full suite of servicesacross three core verticals: Data Centre Solutions, Managed ITServices, and Business Internet. Our data centre infrastructureensures maximum uptime, security, and scalability - so when your ITruns right, your people and your business thrive.

    This news release was prepared on behalf of the Boardof Directors, which accepts full responsibility for itscontents.

    Learn more at www.uniserve.com or at www.sedarplus.ca.

    Kwin Grauer

Uniserve cautions that actualfinancial results could differ materially from the currentexpectations due to a number of factors.

data.title: Corn, soybean futures steady in quiet trade
data.description:
Spot basis bids for corn and soybeans were flat in the U.S. Midwest on Thursday in quiet trade while corn and soybean futures traded on both sides of unchanged, spot checks showed.

  • The wheat basis fell at an Ohio port.

  • U.S. soybean futures rallied on Thursday to their highest level since mid-2024 on hopes for more U.S. biofuel demand and Chinese imports before the market eased in a profit-taking retreat.

  • Corn futures also declined on profit-taking and technical selling, and as weekly corn export sales fell below trade expectations, while wheat firmed following three sessions of losses.

  • The U.S. Department of Agriculture reported weekly net soybean export sales at 407,100 tons, on the low end of a range of analyst expectations.

data.title: Time for Investors to Get Defensive. Sell Staples and Buy Healthcare. — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Jacob Sonenshine

Investors have plenty of reason to move into defensive stocks. The best way to do it: Sell consumer staples and buy healthcare.

For starters, the broader market is looking a little shaky. The S&P 500 has gone nowhere for about four months.

Software stocks have fallen off a cliff on the back of competitive threats from the major artificial-intelligence innovators. The market will sort thought which software vendors can stand strong and which will fall, leaving the sector somewhat of a land mine.

Meanwhile, semiconductor stocks have rallied, but they are giving back a bit of the gain Thursday, even after Nvidia's stellar guidance, indicating that chip stocks have already priced in much of their expected growth. All in all, there are plenty of potential pressure points on the S&P 500.

That's why adding less-volatile stocks to one's portfolio makes sense. The consumer staples, healthcare, and utilities sectors have consistent sales and earnings because aggregate demand for items such as toiletries, groceries, drugs, medical devices, health insurance, and electricity tends to remain relatively stable, no matter what's happening in the economy.

Buying exposure to those sectors today is less straightforward. The best strategy is to sell staples and use the proceeds to rotate into healthcare.

The Vanguard Consumer Staples Index exchange-traded fund has ripped higher — and looks unattractive. It is up 16% from a multi-month low in early January after having badly underperformed the S&P for years. It was time for staples to enjoy a catch-up trade, so in the past few weeks many market strategists have noted that the group looks overbought. The chart of the past few weeks traces a straight line upward, which means that many investors who wanted more exposure to the sector have already bought in. Going forward, demand for these shares should fade.

Fading these hot stocks now makes sense because they're more expensive in the face of weakening fundamentals. Only about 29% of analysts' revisions of 2026 earnings estimates for staples have been upward, according to FactSet, while a little more than half of 2026 revisions for all S&P 500 companies have been upward. Many staples face the possibility of declining business in the long term. Companies such as PepsiCo, Kraft-Heinz, Utz Brands, Mondelez, Hershey, General Mills, Campbell's, Conagra Brands, and J.M. Smucker are facing headwinds from healthier food options. Staples just might not deserve their current valuations.

Healthcare is a better bet. Companies in the sector don't appear vulnerable to AI or any other kind of disruption. The analyst community seems calm. About 63% of all 2026 earnings revisions for the sector have been upward.

Analysts expect growth. Medical-device makers are expected to grow sales for the long term, as demand for certain types of surgeries rises. Drugmakers are seeing a growth tailwind from GLP-1 weight-loss drugs. Health insurance recently endured a disappointing announcement from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services on funding for insurers, but the stocks look like they have already reflected that setback. Already, UnitedHealth Group, which bottomed this year at $268, has stabilized and is now at $287.

UnitedHealth is an important stock in the healthcare sector, with its $261 billion market capitalization representing almost 5% of the S&P 500 Health Care Sector index's total market cap. Further gains in UnitedHealth, which plans to replace certain costs with AI to increase its profit margins and earnings, would support gains in the State Street Health Care Select Sector SPDR ETF.

Analysts expect about 6% aggregate annual sales growth for the fund, according to FactSet. That, combined with higher margins, should drive 10% earnings growth annually.

That prospect for growth makes its valuation look tolerable. The fund trades at 20.5 times expected earnings for the coming 12 months, just under the S&P 500's 21.9 times. That's not the cheapest it's ever been, but it's normal. It often trades somewhere between a few points below the index and a few points above it. As long as earnings grow close to expectations, the stocks can rise over the next few years.

This little tweak — selling staples and buying healthcare — could do wonders for one's portfolio if the market heads south.

Write to Jacob Sonenshine at jacob.sonenshine@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Bank of Mexico Raises Forecast for 2026 Economic Growth
data.description:
By Anthony Harrup

MEXICO CITY--The Bank of Mexico increased its forecast for economic growth this year following a better-than-expected performance in the fourth quarter of 2025.

In its quarterly economic report Thursday, the central bank said it expects gross domestic product to expand 1.6% in 2026, up from its previous estimate of 1.1%. The bank left its GDP forecast at 2.0% for 2027.

The central bank said it still sees moderately faster growth, although from a higher base than previously estimated.

In the fourth quarter, Mexico's GDP grew 0.9% seasonally adjusted from the previous quarter, while third-quarter GDP was revised up to a 0.1% expansion from a previously estimated 0.3% contraction. The economy grew 0.6% in 2025.

Private consumption growth is expected to accelerate gradually in 2026, while investment is likely to remain weak, at least until the second half of the year given uncertainty about the trade relationship with the U.S. and the coming review of the U.S.-Mexico Canada Agreement, the Bank of Mexico said. Exports are expected to continue with moderate growth.

The balance of risks for growth remains tilted to the downside, the central bank said. Downside risks include greater trade uncertainty with the U.S., geopolitical conflicts that may hurt global growth and trade, and Mexico's higher tariffs on countries with which it doesn't have a trade agreement.

Upside risks to its forecast include a successful USMCA review, and the 2026 soccer World Cup which Mexico is co-hosting with the U.S. and Canada, and higher-than-expected U.S. economic growth, the central bank said.

Write to Anthony Harrup at anthony.harrup@wsj.com

data.title: Nordic American Tankers Ltd reports results for the quarter ended December 31 - Earnings Summary
data.description:
• Nordic American Tankers Ltd reported quarterly adjusted earnings of 6 cents​​ per share for the quarter ended December 31, higher than the same quarter last year, when the company reported EPS of 1 cents. The mean expectation of three analysts for the quarter was for earnings of 2 cents per share. Wall Street expected results to range from 9 cents to 18 cents per share.

  • Revenue fell 12.2% to $58.76 million from a year ago; analysts expected $72.17 million.

  • Nordic American Tankers Ltd's reported EPS for the quarter was 6 cents​.

  • The company reported a quarterly loss of $2.78 million.

  • Nordic American Tankers Ltd shares had risen by 46.5% this quarter.

FORECAST CHANGES

  • The mean earnings estimate of analysts had risen by about 13% in the last three months.​

  • In the last 30 days, there have been no negative revisions of earnings estimates

RECOMMENDATIONS

  • The current average analyst rating on the shares is "buy" and the breakdown of recommendations is 3 "strong buy" or "buy," 1 "hold" and no "sell" or "strong sell." The average consensus recommendation for the oil & gas transportation services peer group is also "buy"

  • Wall Street's median 12-month price target for Nordic American Tankers Ltd is $5.00, about 0.8% below its last closing price of $5.04

This summary was machine generated from LSEG data February 26 at 07:50 p.m. UTC. ​All figures in US dollars unless otherwise stated.
